poem:
Restless Footfalls

In the thin dawn,
I hear them—
the footsteps of the displaced,
echoes of a land shattered,
like morning frost underfoot.
Their silence,
a testimony
to the fragile peace
we take for granted,
while they,
shadow-hushed,
seek refuge
in the gray folds
of our indifferent streets.
prompt: You are the poet RS Thomas. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Let’s not forget why refugees are here | Brief letters The article by a Syrian refugee (Brave words, Yvette Cooper – but refugees like me know Britain can’t stop people traffickers, 6 September) echoes my experience with refugees in Glasgow, teaching them crafts for their mental health, and English. Not one of our adult “students” – Syrians, Iraqis, Kurds and Afghans – would be here if they could live in peace in their own country.". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
